instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CPUIMVP_VR_ON: What is CPUIMVP_VR_ON? CPUIMVP_VR_ON is a signal that tells the buck converter responsible for PPVCORE_S0_CPU to turn on and create CPU vcore voltage. This comes from ALL_SYS_PWRGD â€“ once ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present, CPUIMVP_VR_ON will be present. .
definitions.CPUIMVP_PGOOD: What is CPUIMVP_PGOOD? CPUIMVP_PGOOD is a signal from the CPU VCORE buck converter IC that indicates CPU power is good which is necessary to create PM_S0_PGOOD..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No CPU Vcore
threads.message: This computer was pretty mangled by liquid-damage and ensuing shorts. I had it working fine and then it lost CPU Vcore after a couple weeks. I tested the voltages around <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and everything looks good. No <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_PGOOD</SIGNAL> but I'm not sure what triggers that to come on. <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_TONA</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_TONB</SIGNAL> resistors are good. Voltage is traveling through them properly - voltage measures fine at pins 1 and 48 on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>. <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_VR_ON</SIGNAL> is good. The 5V line is everywhere it needs to be. No output (0.005V) at PHASE! and UGATE1. Any ideas on a next move?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No CPU Vcore
threads.message:
Probably corrosion under the SMC or PCH. There is no diagnosis for this and that is why boards with this issue suck. Put some flux and some heat on SMC/PCH, do NOT reflow, just 150C.

But could basically be any resistor or trace somewhere.......

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No CPU Vcore
threads.message:
I forgot to mention that the fan spins.

Ok, I'll try cleaning under those chips. What kind of flux do you recommend for this? I've been trying to use Amtech 559 and heating it up so it will liquify flow under the chip but I don't think it's working so well. I've used Kester too but it seems substantially more toxic.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No CPU Vcore
